q: What are the main ways to get hepatitis B?
a: Hepatitis B is mainly spread through having unprotected sex, sharing needles, or coming into contact with infected blood, semen, or vaginal fluids.

q: How can I prevent hepatitis B?
a: The best way to prevent hepatitis B is to get vaccinated. Additionally, using condoms, avoiding sharing razors or needles, and practicing safe hygiene can help reduce the risk of infection.

q: What are the symptoms of hepatitis B?
a: Symptoms of hepatitis B can include fatigue, abdominal pain, nausea, itching, jaundice (yellowing of the skin and eyes), and fever. However, many people with hepatitis B may not experience any symptoms at all.

q: What should I do if I think I have hepatitis B?
a: If you suspect you have hepatitis B, it is important to see a GP for further evaluation and testing. They can provide guidance on the next steps and appropriate treatment options.

q: What treatments are available for hepatitis B?
a: In most cases, hepatitis B clears up on its own without treatment. However, if necessary, medications can be prescribed to manage symptoms and antiviral drugs may be used for long-term cases. Regular check-ups with a liver specialist are also important.

q: How can I live with hepatitis B?
a: Living with hepatitis B involves practicing good self-care, including rest, staying hydrated, avoiding alcohol, and practicing safe sex. It is also important to take prescribed medications and attend regular check-ups with a liver specialist.

q: What are the complications of hepatitis B?
a: If left untreated, hepatitis B can lead to liver damage (cirrhosis) and increase the risk of liver cancer. Regular monitoring and adherence to prescribed treatments can help prevent complications.

q: Who is at high risk for hepatitis B?
a: People at higher risk for hepatitis B include those who have unprotected sex, share needles, or come into contact with infected blood, semen, or vaginal fluids. Individuals with liver or kidney disease, HIV, and certain occupations (such as healthcare workers) may also be at higher risk.

q: Can hepatitis B be passed from a pregnant mother to her baby?
a: Yes, if a pregnant woman has hepatitis B, there is a risk of passing the infection to the baby during pregnancy or birth. Vaccination and other preventive measures can be taken to reduce this risk.

q: What happens if hepatitis B becomes chronic?
a: If hepatitis B persists for more than 6 months, it is considered chronic. In such cases, it may lead to long-term liver problems, including cirrhosis and an increased risk of liver cancer. Medical treatment and regular monitoring are important for managing chronic hepatitis B.

q: How is hepatitis B transmitted?
a: Hepatitis B is transmitted through blood, semen, and vaginal fluids. It can be acquired through unprotected sex, sharing needles, tattoo or piercing with unsterilized equipment, or blood transfusion in a country that does not check for hepatitis B.

a: Symptoms of hepatitis B infection include high temperature, tiredness, pain in the upper tummy, nausea or vomiting, itchy hives, and yellowing of the skin and eyes (jaundice).

a: Hepatitis B usually clears up on its own without treatment. Medication can be prescribed to manage symptoms. In chronic cases, antivirals and medications to relieve symptoms are used. Regular check-ups with a liver specialist are necessary.

q: What can I do to prevent the spread of hepatitis B?
a: To prevent the spread of hepatitis B, it is important to rest, stay hydrated, take recommended painkillers, keep the room well-ventilated, avoid hot showers and baths if feeling itchy, avoid alcohol, practice safe sex, and not share personal items like razors, toothbrushes, or needles.

q: Can hepatitis B cause complications?
a: If left untreated, chronic hepatitis B can lead to liver damage (cirrhosis) and increase the risk of liver cancer. It is crucial to follow prescribed medications and attend regular check-ups to ensure proper liver function.

q: Are there higher risk areas for hepatitis B?
a: The risk of hepatitis B is higher in some parts of the world, including Africa, Asia, the Middle East, and parts of South America and eastern Europe.

q: Who should get the hepatitis B vaccine?
a: In the UK, the hepatitis B vaccine is given to babies as part of the 6-in-1 vaccine. Adults should get vaccinated if they are at high risk, such as traveling to a high-risk country, having liver or kidney disease, having HIV, or having a profession that puts them at risk.

q: What are the long-term effects of hepatitis B?
a: If hepatitis B lasts for more than 6 months, it is considered chronic. Chronic hepatitis B is usually treated with antivirals and medications to relieve symptoms. Regular check-ups with a liver specialist are necessary.
